datafield.subfield: hh08 2018-01-08 gift contact letter sent per MoR for Todd Harvey LS/AFC - awaiting materials
Joseph C. Mele collection of dialect recordings from the University of South Alabama.
University of South Alabama Dialect Tape Center collection
The collection is arranged alphabetically by state in the United States, and then by city, county, or region; then alphabetically by non-U.S. countries.

Audio recordings of American English dialects from the University of South Alabama, Doy Leale McCall Rare Book & Manuscript Library's Dialect Tape Center collection created by Professor Joseph C. Mele, a former faculty member, between 1975-1980. The collection includes 305 audiocassettes of 30-minute dialect samples recorded by Dr. Mele from individuals in 31 states in the United States, particularly in the South, with more numerous recordings made in Alabama, Tennessee, North Carolina, Virginia, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Missouri. In addition, 41 recordings were made of English spoken by non-American people from 23 different countries in Asia, Europe, and Australia, as well as in Mexico, Panama, and in Nigeria. The birth year of each speaker is documented and ranges from the 1890s to 1950s. Samples generally consist of two parts: an impromptu monologue and a 44 sentence sequence highlighting each American English phoneme.

Recording locations in the United States include: Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida; Savannah, Georgia; Chicago, Illinois; Indiana; Barkley, Kansas; Kentucky; Louisiana; Baltimore, Maryland; Massachusetts; Michigan; Minnesota; Mississippi; Missouri; Montana; New York; North Carolina; Ohio; Pennsylvania; Rhode Island; South Carolina; South Dakota; Tennessee; Texas; Virginia; Washington (State); West Virginia; and Wisconsin from 1975-1980.

Approximately 41 recordings, with some countries represented by a single tape, were made of speakers of English from 23 nations including Australia, China, England, France, Germany, Haiti, Holland, India, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Mexico, Nigeria, Panama, Philippines, Puerto Rico, Romania, Scotland, South Vietnam, Sri Lanka, Spain, Sweden, and Yugoslavia from 1975-1980.
Joseph C. Mele collection of dialect recordings from the University of South Alabama (AFC 2018/004), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
Collection is open for research. Access to recordings may be restricted. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
Duplication of sound recordings may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.
University of South Alabama, Doy Leale McCall Rare Book & Manuscript Library;
Selections from this collection were acquired by the American Folklife Center in 1986 as part of the Center for Applied Linguistics collection (AFC 1986/022) and some are available online.

Professor Joseph Charles Mele, professor of speech, speech pathology, audiology, and drama at the University of South Alabama. He was a graduate of Louisiana State University, and previously held positions at Louisiana State University, the University of Alabama, and the University of Louisiana-Lafayette. Born in Hammond, Louisiana, he died January 12, 2018 in Mobile, Alabama, at the age of 85.
Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center,
101 Independence Ave. S.E., Washington, DC USA 20540-4610
University of South Alabama, Doy Leale McCall Rare Book & Manuscript Library
